posts.name: Matiah
posts.cooked:
This will be our teamâ€™s first year designing an elevator and we need some beginner advice. Weâ€™ve built the Thrifty Bot elevator kit, and weâ€™ve determined that a 2 stage elevator with our height constraints will be able to translate our end-effector a large enough distance to reach L4 as it doesnâ€™t  but the carriage itself is not high enough to reach the height needed. Our current design uses two extra tubes attached to elevator to get the extra height at full extension, with the tops of the tubes below the height limit when contracted, but Iâ€™m not sure this is the most robust way to do it?

2 stage example 1 383Ã—584 93.7 KB

2 stage example 1 383Ã—584 93.7 KB

2 stage example 1 383Ã—584 93.7 KB

Iâ€™m wondering if it would be more robust to build essentially a 2 stage elevator that is like a 3 stage elevator design but without the carriage. However, given our limited experience, we donâ€™t know how to do the rigging for this kind of elevator, and an advantage of using the above traditional 2 stage design is that we can just essentially use the published Thriftybot CAD and stick some tubes on it.

So two questions: 1) Do you think the first example above with tubes to reach above the carriage will be an effective solution or would it be more effective for us to make something more like a 3 stage elevator without the carriage? and 2) Has anyone already created a 3 stage or carriage-less 2 stage version of the Thriftybot elevator that you are willing to share? I realize that we could probably figure it out and create our own design, but with a small team with limited resources and no elevator experience, Iâ€™d rather have the students focus on the end effectors and other elements of the robot.

posts.name: Dan_Karol
posts.cooked:
Both methods can work.  The extended carriage is similar to what we did in 2024 to help our launcher clear the top of our lift.

Lift only:

Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 4 million users.

Post about the full robot:

CHAOS 131 CAD Release - 2024 "Double Time" CAD

posts.name: Matiah
posts.cooked: Cool, I appreciate it. I like your version of extending the carriage without adding extra tubes.

posts.name: Casey Stahl - 2358 - Robot Repairman (Mentor)
posts.cooked:
I think youâ€™re looking for something like what weâ€™re doing.  The base stage (aka stage 0) doesnâ€™t move.  This and Stage one have the top rail moved to the back side of the elevator to allow for higher extension of stage 1 and the stage 2 carriage.  The rail still provides the rigidity.  Make sure to keep a minimum overlap between each stage to keep things rigid.  Hope this helps.

posts.name: Brandon Liatys
posts.cooked:
shamanm:

We are essentially doing a variation of this. The carriage is only needed if youâ€™re going to the floor to pick up coral. We found our design became much simpler by just eliminating the carriage stage, as we chose to not floor pickup in our strategy.

posts.name: Matiah
posts.cooked: Nice, thanks for this example. I think weâ€™ll probably go for something like this.

posts.name: Matiah
posts.cooked: Yes, exactly. Since our team has decided not to go for Coral floor pickup, we donâ€™t need the low minimum height that a carriage provides.

posts.name: P.D
posts.cooked: We are trying to maximize our heightâ€¦ but our stage 2 maxes out on stage 1 long before stage 1 reaches max height.   How have you extended your max height?

posts.name: pogo
posts.cooked: Is it going to be cascade or continuos?

posts.name: Casey Stahl - 2358 - Robot Repairman (Mentor)
posts.cooked:
Depending on your rigging style, there may be different issues. You may want to check out this thread:

Continuous vs cascade lift Technical

There are several other elevator related threads on CD as well which may be of help.

posts.name: P.D
posts.cooked: Currently using a standard thrifty elevator setup, same setup as recommended.  With 2 motors pulling the chain.  We are new to this, I believe its considered cascade?

posts.name: Brandon Liatys
posts.cooked:
Can you show us a picture of your elevator?

Are your stages each a different length?

posts.name: Brandon Liatys
posts.cooked:
Generally, for every inch your first stage moves inside of the stationary frame, the 2nd stage also moves the same distance inside the first stage. (So for every inch you move your chain, your last stage moves 2in).

I donâ€™t think there is anything you can do in a cascade system to change that relationship to allow your carriage to move less per inch so the first stage makes it all the way up. Maybe different pulley diameters on the top and bottom? Someone much smarter then me may be able to answer that.

If theres no way to do that, I think the only solution is to make your middle stage taller if you have enough starting config height to be able to do so.

How much more up are you trying to get out of it?
